The workload for this course in comparison to other courses was ___________.

Overall, the teaching assistant for this course was accessible, organized, and able to explain concepts clearly and thoroughly.
Field trips were well designed and ran smoothly.
I learned a lot from field trips.
How clearly does the instructor provide explanations of conceptual material?
How responsive to student comments was the instructor?
I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:
Apart from how well the course was taught, how valuable is the course to students with interests similar to yours?
Did you participate in a work group as part of this course?

Instructor: Grace Lange  Lange, Grace

Instructor: Grace Lange  Grace Lange
Instructor: Grace Lange  Grace

Instructor: Grace Lange  Grace Lange
Instructor: Grace Lange  Great TA. Great feedback and assistance when asked.

narratives.question_text: What were the strengths and weaknesses of your teaching assistant
comments: Instructor: Grace Lange  I didn't actually interact with the TA at all throughout the course. I felt that she did a fair job grading and making herself available for questions.
Instructor: Grace Lange  Didn't have much contact with her.
Instructor: Grace Lange  I didn't interact too much with Grace, but she was prompt and helpful in emails.

Instructor: Grace Lange  Grace was very receptive and always available to help students outside of class. Her grasp on the material was excellent and she was great at thinking of new ways to try and explain confusing concepts. She did a great job and I really appreciate her help this semester.
Instructor: Grace Lange  Grace was very helpful when I approached her for help with the assignments.
Instructor: Grace Lange  I did not interact with the teaching assistant.

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-14, if you wish
comments: It would be wonderful to have a full intensive course on timber modelling and finance. Although I understand there may not be enough interested students alone in this field. Two classes a week would be great to get into more detail.

Deborah is an excellent lecturer, and so, wonderfully responsive to whether or not students grasp/are engaged with the material she's covering. I wish all my instructors cared as much about students as she does.

Deborah was a great instructor. Even though she was super busy and spread a bit thin, she tried her best to give us what time she had available. This type of competing priorities was super worth it to me to have the chance to learn from someone who is actively practicing in her field right now. Her competing responsibilities to her day job made her too busy for the class but also super interesting to learn from. Deborah is the first female teacher I've had at FES, and it was so wonderful to learn from her and witness her badass-ness.

I loved the course. It was a subject I knew nothing about and didn't particularly care about but now as I am looking for summer internships I'm adding ecosystem finance to the list of possible careers. Deborah is an excellent professor.

narratives.question_text: What were the best aspects of this course?
comments: The pragmatic concepts we learnt on how to model timberland properties. Covering all the quantitative and qualitative aspects as well.
I liked that the instructor had a lot of real-world experience, and a very applied and common-sense approach to the topic. She also has an excellent sense of humor.
The professor is very flexible and provides the students with a lot of time to work on their assignments. Moreover, she is very open to meet and discuss about any questions and suggestions.
Lectures
Lectures were engaging and assignments were well thought out.
I like how the course is taught from a very practical perspective. Also Deborah makes it very interesting.

This course provides a pretty broad overview of environmental and forest finance. Deborah is an expert, and has great examples and stories from the field. She also presents the information in a very approachable/not overly technical way.

One of the best aspects of this course is that it was taught by someone with real experience in forest and ecosystem investment. She was not simply going by a textbook, but giving us real world examples to work with and telling us how to interpret things in real life.
Deborah is very clear in her explanations and she is very fun.
Great content and introduction to environmental markets
The focus is of the class is mostly forest finance but the concepts taught in the class can be applied to other natural resources hence making the skills gain very important.

narratives.question_text: What aspects of this course need the most improvement?
comments: Focusing the readings perhaps so that they are less but more focused. The quantity of readings sometimes led one to become overwhelmed by the content that was explained.
Faster turnaround on assignment grades.

1. This course has a potential to be one of the good courses in FES, and is currently suffering poorly from course design. 2. It would help to segregate course into three sections - finance basis, forestry basics, and forest finance. Finance basic could be a pre-req (ex 1/2 semester Maureen Burke's class or full semester basics of finance in SOM). Forestry basics could be a 1 day 2 hour refresher or discussion done by TA or some other MF student who is good in forestry basics. 3. Forest finance should be a 1/2 semester class, which would decrease the strain of traveling on Deborah, allow her to actually address her knowledge in a more organized manner, and keep students interest in class by matching the pace. 4. The assignments should be all group assignments instead of individual assignment. Ideally cases should be discussed or evaluated to replicate real life deal or work flow. 5. This course should really include some guest speakers ideally people who are investing in timberland or forests or agriculture or ecosystem finance. Firms like Encourage Capital or RMS Capital would be good starting point. 6. Forest finance should combine with Conservation Finance Network to do a Job or Networking Trek in Boston/NYC and give student real life perspective. 7. Another good input would be to bring someone from broader financial industry along with experience in forest finance, who can actually entail difference, similarities, trends, and expectations from the forest finance industry. 8. The course has LOT of repetition and organization of course material is poorly at the moment. If we are talking about evaluation and challenges associated with it, lets do that only in that class. Lets talk about Risk in another one. Most of the lectures at the moments are huge mumble jumble of risk evaluation limitations forestry policy - which is often repeated 15 times over the semester. Referring to Daniel Gross's Energy Project Finance for structure might be a good idea. The drawback of lack of structure is that Deborah has lot of knowledge, experience, and insights to lend to the students, but it gets lost without a good structure. 9. It will be good to introduce students to a few simple sample Forest Finance models as well.
Class timing
Sometimes it was difficult to reach Deborah with questions about assignments/requests for help.
Scores on the homework assignments need to be returned quicker.
If this course could meet earlier in the week or earlier in the day perhaps it would have fewer time conflicts.
Tutor responsiveness to student questions.
I wish there were make up classes for the ones that were cancelled. Also it is scheduled at the worst time. I had a hard time focusing.

Assignments need to be returned sooner, we could use more practice (i.e., more frequent homework assignments), and the room needs to be changed. The timeslot is necessary given Deborah's work schedule, but the room needs better lighting to accommodate this timeslot. The lectures are fairly dry, and could be improved by shifting the focus to assignments and practice/application (with timely feedback). I feel like this course could benefit from SOM's organization/resources (more assignments, maybe meeting multiple times a week, and more TA's to accommodate more practice) and possibly team teaching to reduce the burden on Deborah.

I feel that the ecosystem services topic was not deep enough. It would be good to have examples beyond mitigation banks. Carbon credits were covered with one example, but I expected more. In addition, it would be good to have more international examples (both for forest and ecosystem services).
The class and the assignments were up to standard from my expectations.

narratives.question_text: Was the relationship between the course lectures and discussion/lab section
comments: The relationship between the course lectures and the assignments was extremely worthwhile.
NA
N/A

It would be helpful for the instructor to have a dedicated office space so scheduling office hours could be more consistent. Its difficult to plan around an instructor who is "on call". Not the fault of the instructor or the school, but the scheduling could be improved.
The class was interesting and the professor brought a lot of practical experiences from her work.

narratives.question_text: Discuss, if you wish, how this course fits into your overall program.  (Please feel free to describe how the course relates to your academic background.)
comments: I am passionate about environmental natural resource investments and this was a perfect fit for my career goals.
I am in the MFS program, but have strong interest in forest management, and this class provides very useful professional skills.

This was a really great complement to the MF program, especially after having completed forest ops and having gone on a couple of field trips. I know some students wanted less timber covered, but this is so important to our program!
This course fills one of the requirements for my degree program.
My focus is in water finance and this class provided excellent examples and case studies on capital budgeting and market of ecosystem services.

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: To gain deeper insight into forestry and timberland modelling so that my expertise could be more beneficial to a natural resource investment team.
I am interested in conservation and climate finance.
To know more about forest finance.
It is a requirement of my program to take this class.
I thought it would be a good compliment to the other courses and field trips in the MF curriculum--it was.
Required for an MF
I took this course to gain a better understanding of forest finance, which is something I need to be familiar with for my future career.
To improve my limited understanding of environmental markets. I have focused on one small aspect of this field of study and it was nice to be able to tie in the rest.
my interest in the course was to understand aspects of Payment of ecosystem services.

narratives.question_text: Did the knowledge/skills that you gained from the course meet your expectations ?
comments: Absolutely, although I wish we could have covered more detailed areas regarding different types of timberland modeling.
Yes, I learned what I was hoping and expecting to in this course.

No,I hardly learnt anything. I could have done similar work without ever taking the course and taking knowledge off the internet. This was not because the course content is immaterial. But rather because, I need to sort through a haystack of things that I already know to find a needle worth of things that I do not know.
Yes
Absolutely
Yep, as someone new to finance this gave a great primer of financial mechanisms and planning.
Yes. I learned much more than I thought I would
I gained broad familiarity with the topics and can speak the language, if necessary.
I feel that I know have the adequate resources to continue to build upon my knowledge of forest finance.
No
yes, great content and delivery. i learned quite a lot from the instructors private sector experience
yes it did

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: This course can really use a team-based approach to assignment. Ideally, a team could be a mix of students from Forest background + student from Finance background, such that they can learn from each other as well.
N/A

narratives.question_text: For students who might consider taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: Prepare the readings beforehand and go through the slides beforehand. That way you will get the most from the lectures and assignments and be able to ask thoughtful questions.
I would highly recommend the class. The only advice I would have is be selective with the readings, there is no need to read all of them, only the ones that you need.
Take it!
Take this course! Deborah is one of the best people I've met since starting at FES.
Take it if you are an MF or interested in land management. For people not interested in forestry it might get a little boring.

If you have a strong background in this material, you might consider spending time on other courses. If you know that this is what you'll be doing, certainly take it because Deborah's a great resource.

While the course can be useful to all experience levels, I highly recommend the readings in the beginning of the semester to make sure you have a basic understanding of finance to build upon. You'll get much more out of the course.
Take it if you are interested in forest management and don't have any finance background.
Know excel and understand what financial modeling is before you take this course. It might be difficult if one does not have a fundamental understanding of finance.
The class is interesting and provides skills that can be used across different natural resources.
